Message.Title: Michael Dell and Silver Lake Might Still NOT Win
Message.Msg: Many institutional investors, including Southeastern Asset Management, T. Rowe Price, Yacktman Asset Management and Pzena Investments are against the offer from Dell and Silver Lake. Combined, these shareholders own around 18% of the company, and may still provide a road block to getting a deal done. Dell, who owns 16% of the company, may still not get the opportunity to take his company private, since he is not allowed to vote in the deal. Proxy firm Glass Lewis still has to make its decision on whether Dell's offer is best for shareholders, or whether they should consider alternatives. That decision is expected to come sometime within the next week. Excluding Dell's ownership stake in the company, approximately 43% of shareholders need to vote in favor of the deal for it to pass.

Message.Title: ROI
Message.Msg: So someone is buying Dell shares for $13.38 or so, for a 1.6% ROI after taxes, between now and closure of the deal? Am I the only one that doesn't see that as a good return on exposure and investment? It seems to me that maybe someone is buying this up with the expectation of a better bid arising from someone else, rather than the Michael Dell price being the final price. No matter! There is always someone on the other side of the deal all the way up to the final bid, no matter how little the ROI. I happen to believe that there is another out there with a desire to have Dell without Mike attached.

Message.Title: Institutional lack of ownership
Message.Msg: 68% of shares of Dell are owned by institutions. Pathetic ! If the Dell and State Street deal is so good then why aren't 98% of shares owned by institutions, even if only speculating? Insider ownership would be totally insignificant if it were not for the Carl Icahn listing and Michael Dells ownership. Who is buying all these shares at this level over the past few months that doesn't have to report their significant % of ownership, which has to be over 300 million at this point? Anyone that owns over 5% has to report and any over 10% have to gain approval from the board, but all of those with extensive ownership have to report is my understanding.

Message.Title: ISS, is not a owner of shares. They are a sock puppet.
Message.Msg: If you don't want to be a shareholder of Dell, sell on the open market. I thank god people like icahn are around. A buyback is much better than a special dividend, because the federal government charges too much taxes for the large shareholder in regards to dividends. I would prefer a special, however Icahns proposal is most fair to the large shareholders.

Message.Title: Fraud through Deception?
Message.Msg: Should Michael Dell and the Board of Directors be charged with "Fraud through Deception" by Federal Officers? Are their actions and statements criminal in the First Degree? Is the fraud being perpetrated on shareholders beyond anything ever seen in the history of publicly traded companies? Maybe not, but they are being disingenuous by their actions.

Topic.Title: Michael Dell needs to be fired from Dell

Message.Msg: It's your own fault for buying your DELL shares at too high a price. If you vote "NO" to Mike Dell's very generous $13.65 per share buyout offer then you will have the opportunity to keep your shares. They will likely be trading at $9 or so per share, but you will get to keep your shares. That is capitalism at work. Hope this helps.
